comments.commentBody: The Chenin blanc I tasted in the 1970 with Robert Mondavi was too vegitale - probably from being allowed to grow too vigorously.  Nothing I tasted resemble anything grown in the Loire.  Given the economics of growing wine grapes in the USA I doubt things have improved.

The Germans looked at it differently. The nation as a whole took on the burden of working through what they had done as a people to the Jews of Europe. 70 years later they are still making amends, calling it "Trauerarbeit" (grief-work). I can think of nothing more suitable for our dealing with the slavery (and its racist spawn) that was the basis for the economies of the South and the mills of the north. Let's move from "discussion" to action. It's well beyond time.

You are completely ignorant of how many of our Black citizens who were just minding their own business, i.e., taking responsibility for their individual persons, have been killed or caught up in the criminal justice system due to police oppression.  It is willful blindness to suggest that if we all just saw to our own "individual responsibility," we would all live in peace.  The problems Blow and members of the Black Lives Matter movement are addressing are ones of systemic oppression that lie outside your rosy world of white picket fences and individual responsibility.

When faced by rampant racism, homophobia, misogyny, etc., etc. give me platitudes about "individual responsibility."

Did you know that Ayn Rand wrote fiction? And not particularly well at that.

"Society itself is to blame."

When everyone is responsible, no one is. As for valuing all lives equally, if we all take responsibility for our own lives, we'd not be having this struggle over whose lives matter.

Your next column should be on individual responsibility.

Rock it young lady - rock it hard!
Life is a gift so play it to win -
Most appreciate your attitude - humbled by your inner light -

God Bless and Good Luck!

Victoria, you have already won!!! You are an inspiration to many people. You have already made it and thank you for sharing your experience with us. Best Wishes!!!! It also makes me to realize what a wonderful person Venus is from her support.
I have a feeling that Hodgkin's Lymphoma's ranking is about to drop.
Victoria, for your endurance, your attitude and your focus, in my eyes you've already won the Grand Slam! You are amazing!

and Elke
Martin- thanks for that link. While interesting and tempting, it does not mention the reason for that "name".
Good thing we don't have "smellavision".....

According to Elmer Fudd, it was "smellevision," and it should've happened in 2000 A.D.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d_qvjwLmrHo
Mark Twain wrote a classic story about a coffin, a train journey, and a chunk of Limburger cheese: http://classiclit.about.com/library/bl-etexts/mtwain/bl-mtwain-invalid.htm

and Elke
This puzzle indeed made me SMILE.
Like others , my RUBIK'S CUBE had "sides" first, then FACES. It was not a TREK; more like a pleasant walk by the SEASIDE.
CHEESE reminds me that many of them have smell, o.k." fragrance". Many years ago on a hiking trip in Switzerland, we stopped at a small CHEESE shop to get some supplies. R. liked the name "Appenzeller " and asked for a WEDGE. The sales lady pointed out that is rather "strong ", but R. persisted (with some men there is NO HOPE). We then got on the post bus to take us to our destination (several hours away). It took us a while to realize that people were slowly moving away from us.... I hear ripe Limburger can have similar effects at clearing spaces. PHEW .
Several months ago. Martin and ? (I have a MENTAL BLOCK) had a discussion about cheese forms and "crottin". Would CUBE be that shape?

Apple PIE with a SLAB of cheddar CHEESE.

Diana:

It seems to me that a big problem is that ofttimes Black lives don't matter to each other. They are understandably desperate to matter to someone. They appeal to those in power and with authority, as if only they can effect change and protect Black lives.

The police are trying to protect Black lives from harm, too. The response to pleas for protection is usually more police.

Christianity has been embraced by millions of Chinese people for centuries--this attack by local government officials on the symbol of transcendent meaning and a treasured way of life only manifests their fears, and deeply wounds the dignity and identity of adherents to the Gospel of Jesus Christ.  Indeed, all of us who consider ourselves to be followers of Jesus are also offended by these actions, and we will cry out--to the responsible authorities, and of course to God, to move their hearts and to make the right decision.

Reading the NYT makes you feel that most Chinese are not happy with the government and their political leaders. I just came back from a trip to China and saw most people are in fact happy and free to express their feelings (I believe they have not reached the levels we have in this country, however). Giving credit to NYT, I guess I could have had a different experience if I visited jails and prisoners instead.

Hey, the air pollution situation gets much better this time, after, I heard, that the government had emphasized on the environment about a year ago. I visited Beijing and Qingdao. I thought that the recent slow down of the breakneck development to a still awesome 7% may after all be a great design for the country and its people, and for the world.
"Picking quarrels and stirring up trouble." Don't the Chinese leaders realize how ludicrous such charges sound to the civilized world?

The problem is the statement, "Black Lives Matter" implies that Black lives don't matter to police offices. The statement, itself, ignores the fact that lives do matter to police officers. Their job is, after all, to protect. That they have made serious transgressions does not mean they are not also doing their job.

Your reference to "daily massacres" show little respect for police or citizens whose lives are helped and saved by police officers. It will always be hard to take statements like "Black Lives Matter" seriously when so many other people's lives are involved.
We will be rooting for you, Victoria, in the days ahead. Take very good care. American tennis, yay!

Victoria, there are others in the sports world who have been exactly where you are with Hodgkin’s lymphoma . Chicago Cub first baseman Anthony Rizzo was diagnosed also at age 18:

http://m.mlb.com/news/article/40669742/

Now he is an All-Star...good luck to you...keep pushing!!
Stay well and strong, Victoria!  Life is so precious.  You really deserve every good thing that comes to you. Good luck!
Welcome back....we missed you!

I hope they all stay home. We don't need, and most of us don't want, a professional football team in Los Angeles. We have enough ugly capitalism here as it is, and we have enough gladiator-like sports spectacles to last lifetimes.

Katie Ledecky shocked the U.S. and the world with her record breaking performance. This woman is very talented in what she does and I'm pretty sure she worked really hard to get there. Her story inspires me in what I do as a sports player. It shows me that hard work pays off & you can pursue any dream you have.
No kidding, Gordon! Every team in contention loaded up but the Yanks. Pitchers and hitters available everywhere and Cashman sat on his hands. Isn't it about five years overdue to get rid of him?

Re Cashman: Chill, and appreciate the past, present and hopeful future. The Yanks are still in 1st place and they held on to their top prospects for the first time since the mid-'90s. You apparently agree with Rhoden, who always is in favor of NY teams spending cash to buy players instead of cultivating their own (remember his lobbying for the Knicks to get Carmelo no matter what they had to give up?).
Cashman blows it again.
TV advertising survived the "mute" button on the remote control. No doubt internet advertising will survive the modern-day equivalent.
How high is up?
How many billions of lives would you ruin for a few million dollars?

Jon - I don't know where you got your information that most kidney failures are self-inflicted. I had my first transplant at 24 (31 yrs ago) due to contracting renal disease secondary to a strep throat when I was 7. I've met many like me, as well as those that had certain kidney diseases that ran in their families or experienced a sudden illness. There may some that caused their own kidney failure but that's not what I've witnessed in the many kidney transplant patients I've mentored over the years. There are many causes of renal failure and it's ignorant to say it's usually the pt's own fault. It would be wiser to do a little research prior to making such misinformed statements in a public forum.

This recipe converted me to tofu; it's absolutely delicious. I used just half a jalapeno pepper, almost a pound of green beans, and more garlic and ginger. Served with rice and grilled vegetables, it was a perfect summer dinner. But it took me much longer than the 15 minutes indicated!

I have problems with the politics of the devil. It's one thing to believe in a benevolent all seeing all knowing supernatural being. It's quite a bit different to believe in an all evil all the time supernatural being called the devil. I believe in neither. Partial birth abortions are difficult for everyone involved. As much as many of us (except me) would like to hold sway over what a woman does with her body, it's ultimately her choice. And she will have to live with the choice what she makes. So be it.

We all believe all lives matter. But all lives are not treated as second class citizens. All lives have not been dehumanized beginning with slavery to Jim Crow, through "Red Lining", told you can only live in a Black part of town. The Black Lives Matter movement’s purpose is to bring to light the atrocities inflicted upon Black Americans because for too long, they have gone unnoticed by most.

It is time to find solutions to stop the carnage in our inner cities, to stop the funds allocated for depressed areas from going to other projects and programs the city administrations deem more important. It's time for, "All Men Are Created Equal" to become a reality. We are one nation. And it will be a stronger nation when we start to treat everyone as one and not some as second class citizens.

The Fox debate questions were loaded and aimed at specific candidates: softballs, fastballs - and spitballs (Chris Wallace was, at one point, dripping with invective). The comment from Carson was one of the few debate "grace notes;" while I recognize its tone as idealistic, it is also the most sane attitude, and one I share wholeheartedly.

It is only through our brain that we experience fear & loneliness, anger & love, joy & anguish, frustration & hope... shame & denial. It is how we process our experience of the world - it makes no sense to limit that world for anyone, from a particular racial group, or a particular economic group.

Limiting brain development is truly "cruel and unusual punishment" because it means damaged human beings: emotionally, critically, physically. Human beings are meant to be curious, to explore, to understand, to solve problems; and right now, it's "all hands on deck" to ameliorate climate change, drought, hunger, poisoned waters, abject poverty, and no home for millions upon millions.

I just wish the guys on that platform "got" that and started using their brains to help rather than their donors' wishes to formulate policies to profit them alone.

And with respect, Mr. Blow, when I write, #AllLivesMatter, it's because I believe it.
Yours, mine, ours.
#WeAreOne
